In a similar US paper that year, Ananthakrishnan et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19084483 | doi=10.1016/j.cgh.2008.08.013 | volume=7 | issue=3 | title=Outcomes of weekend admissions for upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage: a nationwide analysis | author=Ananthakrishnan AN, McGinley EL, Saeian K | journal=Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol | pages=296–302e1 | year=2009}}</ref> studied another very large population (of 419,939 patients with UGIB). On multivariate analysis, non-variceal UGIB patients admitted on weekends had higher adjusted in-hospital mortality (OR = 1.21; 95% CI 1.09-1.35). Whereas, weekend admission was not predictive of in-hospital mortality in patients with AVH (OR = 0.94; 95% CI 0.75-1.18).
In another similar US study, by Dorn et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19672711 | doi=10.1007/s10620-009-0914-1 | volume=55 | issue=6 | title=Effect of weekend hospital admission on gastrointestinal hemorrhage outcomes | author=Dorn SD, Shah ND, Berg BP, Naessens JM | journal=Dig Dis Sci | pages=1658–66 | year=2010}}</ref> in 2010, 98,975 patients with UGIB were studied, and a similar weekend effect found. Compared to patients admitted on a weekday, for those admitted on a weekend, in-hospital mortality was higher (unadjusted mortality 3.76 vs 3.33%; p = 0.003; adjusted OR = 1.09, 95% CI 1.00-1.18). Whereas, in a much smaller 2011 UK study (of 6749 patients), Jaraith et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21606977 | doi=10.1038/ajg.2011.172 | volume=106 | issue=9 | title=Mortality from acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding in the United kingdom: does it display a "weekend effect"? | author=Jairath V, Kahan BC, Logan RF, Hearnshaw SA, Travis SP, Murphy MF, Palmer KR | journal=Am J Gastroenterol | pages=1621–8 | year=2011}}{{sic|hide=y}}: does it display a "weekend effect"? Am J Gastroenterol. 2011 Sep; 106(9): 1621-8]</ref> no weekend effect was found in UGIB. After adjustment for confounders, there was no evidence of a difference between weekend and weekday mortality (OR = 0.93; 95% CI 0.75-1.16).
Two further small studies were published in 2012. In South Korea, 388 UGIB (due to peptic ulcer) patients were studied by Youn et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22826623 | doi=10.3748/wjg.v18.i27.3578 | volume=18 | issue=27 | title=Weekend and nighttime effect on the prognosis of peptic ulcer bleeding | pmc=3400860 | author=Youn YH, Park YJ, Kim JH, Jeon TJ, Cho JH, Park H | journal=World J Gastroenterol | pages=3578–84 | year=2012}}</ref> Most patients (97%) had undergone early endoscopy, but the mortality rate was not different between the two groups (1.8% overall vs 1.6% on the weekend). Whereas, in the Netherlands, de Groot et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22747509 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2036.2012.05205.x | volume=36 | issue=5 | title=Admission time is associated with outcome of upper gastrointestinal bleeding: results of a multicentre prospective cohort study | author=de Groot NL, Bosman JH, Siersema PD, van Oijen MG, Bredenoord AJ | journal=Aliment Pharmacol Ther | pages=477–84 | year=2012}}</ref> studied 571 patients with UGIB. The group found patients admitted during the weekend had a higher mortality rate than patients admitted during the week (9% vs 3%; OR = 2.68; 95% CI 1.07-6.72).
In 2014, Abougergi et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24674354 | doi=10.1016/j.gie.2014.01.043 | volume=80 | issue=2 | title=Impact of day of admission on mortality and other outcomes in upper GI hemorrhage: a nationwide analysis | author=Abougergi MS, Travis AC, Saltzman JR | journal=Gastrointest Endosc | pages=228–35 | year=2014}}</ref> in another very large US study (of 202,340 patients) found that (compared with patients admitted on weekdays), patients with non-variceal UGIB admitted on weekends had similar adjusted in-hospital mortality rates (OR = 1.11; 95% CI 0.93-1.30).
In a Scottish study of 60,643 patients with UGIB in 2015, there was no significant change in annual number of admissions over time; but there was a statistically significant reduction in 30-day case fatality from 10.3% to 8.8% (p<0.001) over 10 years (Ahmed et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26478680 | doi=10.3748/wjg.v21.i38.10890 | volume=21 | issue=38 | title=Upper gastrointestinal bleeding in Scotland 2000-2010: Improved outcomes but a significant weekend effect | pmc=4600590 | author=Ahmed A, Armstrong M, Robertson I, Morris AJ, Blatchford O, Stanley AJ | journal=World J Gastroenterol | pages=10890–7 | year=2015}}</ref>). Patients admitted with UGIB at weekends had a higher 30-day case fatality compared with those admitted on weekdays (p<0.001), after adjusting for comorbidities.
In 2016, Serrao et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26972023 | doi=10.1016/j.gie.2016.02.046 | volume=84 | issue=3 | title=In-hospital weekend outcomes in patients diagnosed with bleeding gastroduodenal angiodysplasia: a population-based study, 2000 to 2011 | author=Serrao S, Jackson C, Juma D, Babayan D, Gerson LB | journal=Gastrointest Endosc | pages=416–23 | year=2016}}</ref> in the US, studied 85,971 patients with bleeding gastroduodenal angiodysplasia (GIAD). Mortality rates were higher for patients with weekend admission (2% vs 1%, p=0 .0002). And the adjusted odds ratio for inpatient mortality associated with weekend admission was elevated (OR = 2.4; 95% CI 1.5-3.9; p=0.0005)
Also in 2016, Weeda et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27534406 | doi=10.1007/s11739-016-1522-7 | title=Association between weekend admission and mortality for upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage: an observational study and meta-analysis | author=Weeda ER, Nicoll BS, Coleman CI, Sharovetskaya A, Baker WL | journal=Intern Emerg Med | volume=12 | issue=2 | pages=163–169 | year=2016}}</ref> in the USA, studied 119,353 patients in a metanalysis (of five studies, including their own. They found weekend admission for nonvariceal UGIB was associated with an increased odds of mortality (OR = 1.09; 95% CI 1.04-1.15).
'''''UGIB (Variceal haemorrhage alone)''''' In a Canadian study of 36,734 patients with AVH alone, Myers et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19623333 | volume=23 | issue=7 | title=The effect of weekend versus weekday admission on outcomes of esophageal variceal hemorrhage | pmc=2722470 | author=Myers RP, Kaplan GG, Shaheen AM | journal=Can J Gastroenterol | pages=495–501 | doi=10.1155/2009/713789 | year=2009}}</ref> (2009—after adjusting for confounding factors, including the timing of endoscopy - found that the risk of mortality was similar between weekend and weekday admissions (OR = 1.05; 95% CI 0.97-1.14). Similarly, in a much smaller South Korean study (of 294 AVH patients), Byun et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmc=3282972 | pmid=22318819 | doi=10.3349/ymj.2012.53.2.318 | volume=53 | issue=2 | title=Acute variceal hemorrhage in patients with liver cirrhosis: weekend versus weekday admissions | author=Byun SJ, Kim SU, Park JY, Kim BK, Kim DY, Han KH, Chon CY, Ahn SH | journal=Yonsei Med J | pages=318–27 | year=2012}}</ref> (2012), found no weekend effect; when seventeen (23.0%) of 74 patients with a weekend admission and 48 (21.8%) of 220 with a weekday admission died during hospitalisation (p=0.872).
'''''Other Gastroenterological Disease''''' In 2016, in the US, Gaeteno et al. investigated 31,614 with cirrhosis and ascites. Among these admissions, approximately 51% (16,133) underwent paracentesis. Patients admitted on a weekend demonstrated less frequent use of early paracentesis (50% weekend vs 62% weekday) and increased mortality (OR = 1.12; 95% CI 1.01-1.25).
Two US studies of acute cholangitis were also published in 2016. Firstly, Inamdar et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26782818 | doi=10.1038/ajg.2015.425 | volume=111 | issue=3 | title=Weekend vs. Weekday Admissions for Cholangitis Requiring an ERCP: Comparison of Outcomes in a National Cohort | author=Inamdar S, Sejpal DV, Ullah M, Trindade AJ | journal=Am J Gastroenterol | pages=405–10 | year=2016}}</ref> identified 23,661 patients who were admitted for cholangitis who required ERCP; of which 18,106 (76.5%) patients were admitted on the weekday, and 5,555 (23.5%) admitted on the weekend. By 24h, the weekday group had undergone ERCP more frequently than the weekend group (54.6 vs 43%; p<0.001). There was no statistical difference between the groups for in-hospital all-cause mortality (2.86 vs 2.56%; p=0.24), or length of stay (6.97 days vs 6.88 days; p=0.28). Secondly, in a much smaller study (of 181 patients), Tabibian et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26391268 | doi=10.1007/s10620-015-3853-z | volume=61 | issue=1 | title=Weekend Admission for Acute Cholangitis Does Not Adversely Impact Clinical or Endoscopic Outcomes | year=2016 | journal=Dig. Dis. Sci. | pages=53–61 | author=Tabibian JH, Yang JD, Baron TH, Kane SV, Enders FB, Gostout CJ}}</ref> found no significant differences in mortality between weekend and weekday admission groups.
In a Japanese study, also in 2016, Hamada et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26897739 | doi=10.1007/s00535-016-1179-z | volume=51 | issue=11 | title=No weekend effect on outcomes of severe acute pancreatitis in Japan: data from the diagnosis procedure combination database | author=Hamada T, Yasunaga H, Nakai Y, Isayama H, Matsui H, Fushimi K, Koike K | journal=J Gastroenterol | pages=1063–1072 | year=2016}}</ref> studied 8328 patients hospitalised with severe acute pancreatitis. In-hospital mortality rates were not significantly different: 5.9% vs 5.4% for weekend and weekday admissions, respectively (OR = 1.06; 95% CI 0.83-1.35).
In summary, there is reasonable evidence (from larger studies) of a ‘weekend effect’ in UGIB (including bleeding gastroduodenal angiodysplasia) and paracentesis for cirrhosis and ascites; but little effect in AVH alone, and none in ERCP for cholangitis, or pancreatitis.
===Nephrology and transplantation=== In a very large Canadian study (of 963,730) patients, in 2010, James et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20395373 | doi=10.1681/ASN.2009070682 | volume=21 | issue=5 | title=Weekend hospital admission, acute kidney injury, and mortality | pmc=2865737 | author=James MT, Wald R, Bell CM, Tonelli M, Hemmelgarn BR, Waikar SS, Chertow GM | journal=J Am Soc Nephrol | pages=845–51 | year=2010}}</ref> showed that (compared with admission on a weekday), AKI patients admitted on a weekend had a higher risk of death (OR = 1.07; 95% CI 1.02-1.12). Similarly, in a huge study of 3,278,572 American haemodialysis patients in 2013, Sakhuja et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23669002 | doi=10.1053/j.ajkd.2013.03.014 | volume=62 | issue=4 | title=Outcomes of patients receiving maintenance dialysis admitted over weekends | pmc=3783620 | author=Sakhuja A, Schold JD, Kumar G, Dall A, Sood P, Navaneethan SD | journal=Am J Kidney Dis | pages=763–70 | year=2013}}</ref> concluded that patients admitted over weekends had higher mortality during the first 3 days of admission (OR = 1.18; 95% CI 1.10-1.26).
Haddock et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26610796 | doi=10.1177/0036933015619293 | volume=61 | issue=4 | title=In-patient hospital mortality patterns by day of the week: an analysis of admissions to a regional renal unit | author=Haddock R, Deighan C, Thomson PC | journal=Scott Med J | pages=179–184 | year=2016}}</ref> in the UK, in 2015, studied admissions to a renal unit. No weekend effect was observed. Thirty-day mortality rate was 46/208 = 0.22 deaths/weekend day of admission compared with 107/523 = 0.20 deaths/weekday of admission (OR = 1.08, p = 0.67). Acute kidney injury and haemodialysis patients formed a higher percentage of admissions.
Orman et al.,<ref> {{cite journal | pmid = 22271668 | doi=10.1002/lt.23395 | pmc=3334405 | volume=18 | issue=5 | title=Impact of nighttime and weekend liver transplants on graft and patient outcomes | author=Orman ES, Hayashi PH, Dellon ES, Gerber DA, Barritt | journal=Liver Transpl | pages=558–65 | year=2012}}</ref> in 2012, in the USA, studied 94,768 liver transplants. The patient survival rates did not significantly differ from those for daytime and weekday operations. The graft failure rate was unchanged at 30 and 90 days for weekend transplants but was modestly increased at 365 days (OR = 1.05; 95% CI 1.01-1.11).
In 2016, an American study of 181,799 deceased donor kidneys was carried out by Mohan et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27182001 | doi=10.1016/j.kint.2016.03.007 | volume=90 | issue=1 | title=The weekend effect alters the procurement and discard rates of deceased donor kidneys in the United States | pmc=4912390 | author=Mohan S, Foley K, Chiles MC, Dube GK, Patzer RE, Pastan SO, Crew RJ, Cohen DJ, Ratner LE | journal=Kidney Int | pages=157–63 | year=2016}}</ref> They found that organs procured on weekends, when compared with weekday kidneys, were significantly more likely to be discarded than transplanted (OR = 1.16; 95% CI 1.13–1.19). This was even after adjusting for organ quality (adjusted OR = 1.13; 95% CI 1.10–1.17). Of concern, was that the kidneys discarded at the weekend, were of a significantly higher quality than weekday discards (Kidney Donor Profile Index: 76.5% vs 77.3%).
In another study in 2016, Anderson et al.,<ref>{{cite journal| pmid=27755501 | doi=10.1097/TP.0000000000001522 | volume=101 | issue=9 | title=Outcomes After Weekend Admission for Deceased Donor Kidney Transplantation: A Population Cohort Study | year=2017 | author=Anderson BM, Mytton JL, Evison F, Ferro CJ, Sharif A | journal=Transplantation | pages=2244–2252}}</ref> in the UK, studied 12,902 deceased-donor kidney alone transplants performed in 19 English transplant centres. In a Cox regression model, transplantation at the weekend was not associated with increased 1 year mortality, rehospitalisation or allograft failure/rejection.
In summary, in nephrology, and in aspects of renal and liver transplantation (not mortality), a weekend effect is (variably)seen. This is surprising as both renal and liver medicine usually do not vary clinical practice through the weekend.
===Haematology-oncology and other medical specialties=== In a small study of 422 patients in 2010 with Acute Myeloid Leukaemia, also in the US, Bejanyan et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20564070 | doi=10.1002/cncr.25086 | volume=116 | issue=15 | title=Impact of weekend admissions on quality of care and outcomes in patients with acute myeloid leukemia | author=Bejanyan N, Fu AZ, Lazaryan A, Fu R, Kalaycio M, Advani A, Sobecks R, Copelan E, Maciejewski JP, Sekeres MA | journal=Cancer | pages=3614–20 | year=2010}}</ref> did not see a difference in mortality based on day of admission. Similarly, in a much larger US study (of 12,043 patients with acute leukaemia), in 2014, Goodman et al.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Goodman EK, Reilly AF, Fisher BT, Fitzgerald J, Li Y, Seif AE, Huang YS, Bagatell R, Aplenc R | date = Oct 2014 | title = Association of weekend admission with hospital length of stay, time to chemotherapy, and risk for respiratory failure in pediatric patients with newly diagnosed leukemia at freestanding US children's hospitals | journal = JAMA Pediatr | volume = 168 | issue = 10| pages = 925–31 | pmid = 25155012 | doi=10.1001/jamapediatrics.2014.1023 | pmc=4404706}}</ref> found that those admitted on the weekend did not have an increased mortality (OR = 1.0; 95% CI 0.8-1.6).
Conversely, in a large study (534,011) of US patients with metastatic carcinoma of the prostate also in 2014, Schimd et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25099032 | doi=10.1111/bju.12891 | volume=116 | issue=6 | title=An evaluation of the 'weekend effect' in patients admitted with metastatic prostate cancer | author=Schmid M, Ghani KR, Choueiri TK, Sood A, Kapoor V, Abdollah F, Chun FK, Leow JJ, Olugbade K Jr, Sammon JD, Menon M, Kibel AS, Fisch M, Nguyen PL, Trinh QD | journal=BJU Int | pages=911–9 | year=2015}}</ref> did show a weekend effect. In multivariate analysis, weekend admission was associated with an increased likelihood of complications (OR = 1.15, 95% CI 1.11-1.19) and mortality (OR = 1.20; 95% CI 1.14- 1.27).
Lapointe-Shaw et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27407127 | volume=14 | issue=7 | title=Care and Outcomes of Patients With Cancer Admitted to the Hospital on Weekends and Holidays: A Retrospective Cohort Study | author=Lapointe-Shaw L, Abushomar H, Chen XK, Gapanenko K, Taylor C, Krzyzanowska MK, Bell CM | journal=J Natl Compr Canc Netw | pages=867–74 | year=2016}}</ref> in Canada in 2016, studied 290,471 hospital admissions with cancer. Patients admitted to hospital on weekends/holidays had an increased 7-day in-hospital mortality (4.8% vs 4.3%; OR = 1.13; 95% CI 1.08-1.17); corresponding to 137 excess deaths per year compared with the weekday group. Among those who had procedures in the first 4 days of admission, fewer weekend/holiday-admitted patients had them performed in the first 2 days, for 8 of 9 common procedure groups.
In 2013, Wichmann et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22505303 | doi=10.1136/emermed-2012-201124 | volume=30 | issue=3 | title=Risk factors for 48-hours mortality after prehospital treatment of opioid overdose | author=Wichmann S, Nielsen SL, Siersma VD, Rasmussen LS | journal=Emerg Med J | pages=223–5 | year=2013}}</ref> in a Danish study of 4762 episodes of opiate overdose, found age >50 years and overdose during the weekend significantly associated with 48h mortality.
In summary, in haematology and oncology, two out of three studies showed the weekend effect, both on >100,000 patients.
==Published research: Disease-specific (selected) patients: neuroscience==
===Neurology=== '''''Stroke''''' With myocardial infarction and UGIB, the most well studied disease is stroke, with varying results regarding the weekend effect. Though there are three very large studies (>100,000 patients), two of which are positive.
In the first stroke study, by Saposnik et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17347472 | doi=10.1161/01.STR.0000259622.78616.ea | volume=38 | issue=4 | title=Weekends: a dangerous time for having a stroke? | author=Saposnik G, Baibergenova A, Bayer N, Hachinski V | journal=Stroke | pages=1211–5 | year=2007}}</ref> in 2007, 26,676 patients in 606 hospitals in Canada were assessed. Seven-day stroke mortality was 7.6%. Weekend admissions were associated with a higher stroke mortality than weekday admissions (8.5% vs 7.4%). In the multivariable analysis, weekend admissions were associated with higher early mortality (OR = 1.14; 95% CI 1.02-1.26) after adjusting for age, sex, comorbidities, and medical complications.
In Japan in the following year, a much smaller study of 1578 patients, was carried out by Turin et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 18946216 | doi=10.1159/000165114 | volume=26 | issue=6 | title=Case fatality of stroke and day of the week: is the weekend effect an artifact? Takashima stroke registry, Japan (1988-2003) | author=Turin TC, Kita Y, Rumana N, Ichikawa M, Sugihara H, Morita Y, Tomioka N, Okayama A, Nakamura Y, Ueshima H | journal=Cerebrovasc Dis | pages=606–11 | year=2008}}</ref> They found the 28-day case fatality rate for the weekend admission group was 14.7% (95% CI 11.3-18.8) and 10.1% (95% CI 8.5-11.9) for the weekday admission group. This phenomenon was observed mainly for cerebral infarction, and to some extent for cerebral haemorrhage. But it did not reach statistical significance. In 2009, Tung et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19648828 | doi=10.1097/MLR.0b013e3181a81144 | volume=47 | issue=9 | title=Associations of physician volume and weekend admissions with ischemic stroke outcome in Taiwan: a nationwide population-based study | author=Tung YC, Chang GM, Chen YH | journal=Med Care | pages=1018–25 | year=2009}}</ref> in Taiwan, studied 34,347 ischaemic stroke patients and found that weekend admissions were associated with increased 30-day mortality.
Five studies were published in 2010; three showed a weekend effect. Kazley et al.,<ref name=Kazley>{{cite journal | pmid = 20065127 | doi=10.1001/archneurol.2009.286 | volume=67 | issue=1 | title=Hospital care for patients experiencing weekend vs weekday stroke: a comparison of quality and aggressiveness of care | author=Kazley AS, Hillman DG, Johnston KC, Simpson KN | journal=Arch Neurol | pages=39–44 | year=2010}}</ref> in a US study of 78,657 patients, found no significant difference in mortality depending on day of admission. Similarly, in a larger US study (of 599,087 patients), Hoh et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20724715 | doi=10.1161/STROKEAHA.110.591081 | volume=41 | issue=10 | title=Effect of weekend compared with weekday stroke admission on thrombolytic use, in-hospital mortality, discharge disposition, hospital charges, and length of stay in the Nationwide Inpatient Sample Database, 2002 to 2007 | author=Hoh BL, Chi YY, Waters MF, Mocco J, Barker FG 2nd | journal=Stroke | pages=2323–8 | year=2010}}</ref> also found no difference in in-hospital mortality. Whereas Fang et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21041782 | doi=10.1212/WNL.0b013e3181fb84bc | volume=75 | issue=18 | title=Association between weekend hospital presentation and stroke fatality | author=Fang J, Saposnik G, Silver FL, Kapral MK | journal=Neurology | pages=1589–96 | year=2010}}</ref> in a Canadian study of 20,657 patients, reported that the all-cause 7-day fatality rate was higher in patients seen on weekends compared to weekdays (8.1% vs 7.0%), even after adjustment for age, sex, stroke severity, and comorbid conditions (OR = 1.12, 95% CI 1.00-1.25). Smith et al.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Smith EE, Shobha N, Dai D, Olson DM, Reeves MJ, Saver JL, Hernandez AF, Peterson ED, Fonarow GC, Schwamm LH | date = Oct 2010 | title = Risk score for in-hospital ischemic stroke mortality derived and validated within the Get With the Guidelines-Stroke Program | url = | journal = Circulation | volume = 122 | issue = 15| pages = 1496–504 | doi = 10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.109.932822 | pmid = 20876438 }}</ref> carried out another (much larger) Canadian study with 1036 hospitals contributing 274,988 ischaemic stroke patients. Characteristics associated with in-hospital mortality were age, arrival mode (e.g., via ambulance vs other mode), history of atrial fibrillation, previous stroke, previous myocardial infarction, carotid stenosis, diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, hypertension, history of dyslipidemia, current smoking, and weekend or night admission. In the Netherlands, Ogbu et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20667853 | doi=10.1136/jnnp.2009.202176 | volume=82 | issue=1 | title=A multifaceted look at time of admission and its impact on case-fatality among a cohort of ischaemic stroke patients | author=Ogbu UC, Westert GP, Slobbe LC, Stronks K, Arah OA | journal=J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry | pages=8–13 | year=2011| url=http://dare.uva.nl/personal/pure/en/publications/a-multifaceted-look-at-time-of-admission-and-its-impact-on-casefatality-among-a-cohort-of-ischaemic-stroke-patients(9b7c21d3-e7df-46d6-a5c1-9cfb3c5f8af7).html | format=Submitted manuscript }}</ref> studied 82,219 ischaemic stroke admissions to 115 hospitals. A higher 7-day death risk for weekend admission, when compared to weekday admission, was seen (OR = 1.27; 95% CI 1.20-1.34).
In 2011, McKinney et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21868723 | doi=10.1161/STROKEAHA.110.612317 | volume=42 | issue=9 | title=Comprehensive stroke centers overcome the weekend versus weekday gap in stroke treatment and mortality | author=McKinney JS, Deng Y, Kasner SE, Kostis JB | journal=Stroke | pages=2403–9 | year=2011}}</ref> in the US, studied a much larger number of patients (134,441). Ninety-day mortality was greater in patients with stroke admitted on weekends compared with weekdays (17.2% vs 16.5%; p=0.002). The adjusted risk of death at 90 days was significantly greater for weekend admission (OR = 1.05; 95% CI 1.02-1.09). In a much smaller US study, also in 2011, by O'Brien et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21772968 | doi=10.4061/2011/383012 | volume=2011 | title=Stroke Mortality, Clinical Presentation and Day of Arrival: The Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) Study | pmc=3137964 | author=O'Brien EC, Rose KM, Shahar E, Rosamond WD | journal=Stroke Res Treat | pages=1–8 | year=2011}}</ref> 929 stroke patients were analysed. The overall risk of 28-day mortality was 9.6% for weekday strokes and 10.1% for weekend strokes. However, in a model controlling for patient demographics, risk factors, and event year, weekend arrival was not associated with 28-day mortality (OR = 0.87; 95% CI 0.51-1.50).
Three studies were published in 2012; two showed a weekend effect. Firstly, Palmer et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22777008 | doi=10.1001/archneurol.2012.1030 | volume=69 | issue=10 | title=Dying for the weekend: a retrospective cohort study on the association between day of hospital presentation and the quality and safety of stroke care | author=Palmer WL, Bottle A, Davie C, Vincent CA, Aylin P | journal=Arch Neurol | pages=1296–302 | year=2012}}</ref> in a study of 93,621 UK patients, found the rate of 7-day in-hospital mortality for Sunday admissions was 11.0% (OR = 1.26; 95% CI 1.16-1.37; with Monday used as a reference) compared with a mean of 8.9% for weekday admissions. Secondly, Albright et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23207423 | volume=34 | issue=5–6 | title=Comprehensive stroke centers and the 'weekend effect': the SPOTRIAS experience | pmc=3568158 | author=Albright KC, Savitz SI, Raman R, Martin-Schild S, Broderick J, Ernstrom K, Ford A, Khatri R, Kleindorfer D, Liebeskind D, Marshall R, Merino JG, Meyer DM, Rost N, Meyer BC | journal=Cerebrovasc Dis | pages=424–9 | doi=10.1159/000345077 | year=2012}}</ref> in a study of 8581 patients in the US, reported that weekend admission was not a significant independent predictor of in-hospital mortality (8.4 vs 9.9%, p=0.056), or 90-day mortality (18.2 vs 19.8%, p=0.680). Thirdly, in a Polish study, Niewada et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22426758 | volume=46 | issue=1 | title=Weekend versus weekday admissions in Polish stroke centres -- could admission day affect prognosis in Polish ischaemic stroke patients? | author=Niewada M, Jezierska-Ostapczuk A, Skowrońska M, Sarzyńska-Długosz I, Członkowska A | journal=Neurol Neurochir Pol | pages=15–21 | doi=10.5114/ninp.2012.27209 | year=2012}}</ref> studied 19,667 ischaemic stroke patients, in 72 stroke centres. More patients admitted on weekends died during hospitalisation or had poor outcome at discharge than weekday patients (15.9% and 59.8% vs. 14.1% and 55.3%, respectively).
In 2013 in France, Béjot et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23551852 | doi=10.1111/ene.12154 | volume=20 | issue=8 | title=Stroke care organization overcomes the deleterious 'weekend effect' on 1-month stroke mortality: a population-based study | author=Béjot Y, Aboa-Eboulé C, Jacquin A, Troisgros O, Hervieu M, Durier J, Osseby GV, Giroud M | journal=Eur J Neurol | pages=1177–83 | year=2013}}</ref> in a study of 5864 patients, found that onset during weekends/bank holidays was associated with a higher risk of 30-day mortality during 1985-2003 (OR = 1.26; 95% CI 1.06-1.51; p=0.01), but not during 2004-2010 (OR = 0.99; 95% CI 0.69-1.43; p=0.97). The authors concluded "The deleterious effect of weekends/bank holidays on early stroke mortality disappeared after the organization of a dedicated stroke care network in our community".
In 2014, Bray et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25137386 | doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.1001705 | volume=11 | issue=8 | title=Associations between stroke mortality and weekend working by stroke specialist physicians and registered nurses: prospective multicentre cohort study | pmc=4138029 | author=Bray BD, Ayis S, Campbell J, Cloud GC, James M, Hoffman A, Tyrrell PJ, Wolfe CD, Rudd AG | journal=PLoS Med | pages=e1001705 | year=2014}}</ref> in the UK, studied 56,666 patients in 103 stroke units. The authors found that the highest risk of death was observed in stroke services with the lowest nurse/bed ratios. In multivariable analysis, patients admitted on a weekend to a stroke unit with 1.5 nurses/ten beds had an estimated adjusted 30-d mortality risk of 15.2% (OR = 1.18, 95% CI 1.07-1.29) compared to 11.2% for patients admitted to a unit with 3.0 nurses/ten beds (OR = 0.85, 95% CI 0.77-0.93). The presence of specialist stroke physicians doing daily ward rounds did not have a significant effect on mortality.
Three studies in stroke were published in 2015, one which showed a weekend effect. In the largest study, 47,885 Japanese stroke patients were included (Inoue et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26365617 | doi=10.1016/j.jstrokecerebrovasdis.2015.08.010 | volume=24 | issue=12 | title=Weekend versus Weekday Admission and In-Hospital Mortality from Ischemic Stroke in Japan | author=Inoue T, Fushimi K | journal=J Stroke Cerebrovasc Dis | pages=2787–92 | year=2015}}</ref>). Of these patients, 32.0% were admitted to a Stroke ICU and 27.8% were admitted to a general medical ward (GMW) on a weekend. The estimated in-hospital mortality rate was significantly higher among the patients admitted to a GMW on a weekend compared with those admitted on a weekday (7.9% vs 7.0%), but this difference was not significant after adjusting for the patients' background characteristics. The estimated in-hospital mortality rates of the patients admitted to an S-ICU were similar between weekend and weekday admissions (10.0% vs 9.9%). In a UK stroke study of 37,888 patients, it was found that when compared with weekdays, mortality at seven days was increased significantly; by 19% for admissions on weekends—although the admission rate was 21% lower on weekends (Roberts et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26121338 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0131836 | volume=10 | issue=6 | title=Mortality following Stroke, the Weekend Effect and Related Factors: Record Linkage Study | pmc=4487251 | author=Roberts SE, Thorne K, Akbari A, Samuel DG, Williams JG | journal=PLOS ONE | pages=e0131836 | year=2015}}</ref>). Although not significant, there were indications of increased mortality at seven days for weekend admissions during winter months (31%), in the community (81%) rather than large hospitals (8%) and for patients resident furthest from hospital (32% for distances of >20 kilometres). In a much smaller Spanish study, 1250 patients were described; and no difference was found in in-hospital mortality (Romero Sevilla et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26385014 | doi=10.1016/j.nrl.2015.07.011 | volume=31 | issue=3 | title=A stroke care management system prevents outcome differences related to time of stroke unit admission | author=Romero Sevilla R, Portilla Cuenca JC, López Espuela F, Redondo Peñas I, Bragado Trigo I, Yerga Lorenzana B, Calle Escobar M, Gómez Gutiérrez M, Casado Naranjo I | journal=Neurologia | pages=149–56 | year=2016}}</ref>). Regarding functional outcome at 3 months, 67.0% of weekday vs 60.7% of weekend admissions were independent (p=0.096); as were 65.5% of patients admitted during the academic months vs 3.5% of those admitted during summer holidays (p=0.803). They also identified a trend toward higher rates of thrombolysis administration on weekdays, during the morning shift, and during the academic months.
Four studies have, so far, been published in 2016; three showing a weekend effect, one not. Turner et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26285585 | doi=10.1136/jnnp-2015-311273 | volume=87 | issue=2 | title=Stroke patients admitted within normal working hours are more likely to achieve process standards and to have better outcomes | pmc=4752676 | author=Turner M, Barber M, Dodds H, Dennis M, Langhorne P, Macleod MJ | journal=J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry | pages=138–43 | year=2015}}</ref> in the UK, investigated 52,276 stroke events. OR for seven-day mortality, 30-day mortality and 30-day discharge for weekend admission compared to weekday was 1.17 (95% CI 1.05-1.30), 1.08 (95% CI 1.00 to 1.17) and 0.90 (95% CI 0.85 to 0.95), respectively. A smaller Korean study (of 8957 stroke patients) by Cho et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26654666 | doi=10.1016/j.jstrokecerebrovasdis.2015.10.014 | volume=25 | issue=2 | title=Effect of Weekend Admission on In-Hospital Mortality in Patients with Ischemic Stroke: An Analysis of Korean Nationwide Claims Data from 2002 to 2013 | author=Cho KH, Park EC, Nam CM, Choi Y, Shin J, Lee SG | journal=J Stroke Cerebrovasc Dis | pages=419–27 | year=2016}}</ref> also found evidence of an effect. After adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics, their frailty model analysis revealed significantly higher in-hospital mortality in patients admitted on weekends than in those admitted on weekdays (OR = 1.22; 95% CI 1.01-1.47).
Hsieh et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27336904 | doi=10.1097/MD.0000000000004046 | volume=95 | issue=25 | title="Weekend effect" on stroke mortality revisited: Application of a claims-based stroke severity index in a population-based cohort study | pmc=4998342 | author=Hsieh CY, Lin HJ, Chen CH, Li CY, Chiu MJ, Sung SF | journal=Medicine (Baltimore) | pages=e4046 | year=2016}}</ref> in Taiwan, analysed 46,007 ischaemic stroke admissions. They found, in multivariate analysis without adjustment for stroke severity, weekend admission was associated with increased 30-day mortality (OR = 1.20; 95% CI 1.08-1.34). But this association did not persist after adjustment for stroke severity (OR = 1.07; 95% CI 0.95-1.20). Whereas, Ansa et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27080145 | pmc=5370317 | doi=10.5830/CVJA-2016-025 | volume=27 | issue=5 | title=Patient outcomes following after-hours and weekend admissions for cardiovascular disease in a tertiary hospital in Calabar, Nigeria | author=Ansa V, Otu A, Oku A, Njideoffor U, Nworah C, Odigwe C | journal=Cardiovasc J Afr | pages=328–332 | year=2016}}</ref> in Nigeria in 2016, studied 339 patients, of which 187 (55.2%) had had a stroke. They found presentation to hospital after-hours was a significant predictor of death (OR = 3.37).
There has been one study of stroke in (8467) children, by Adil et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27118791 | doi=10.1161/STROKEAHA.116.013453 | volume=47 | issue=6 | title=Weekend Effect in Children With Stroke in the Nationwide Inpatient Sample | author=Adil MM, Vidal G, Beslow LA | journal=Stroke | pages=1436–43 | year=2016}}</ref> in the US, in 2016. After adjusting for age, sex, and confounders, the odds of in-hospital mortality remained higher among children admitted on weekends (OR = 1.4; 95% CI 1.1-1.9; p=0.04).
'''''Other neurological disease''''' One study related to meningococcal septicaemia has been published. In 2013, Goldacre et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23378233 | doi=10.1093/pubmed/fdt004 | volume=35 | issue=3 | title=Mortality from meningococcal disease by day of the week: English national linked database study | author=Goldacre MJ, Maisonneuve JJ | journal=J Public Health (Oxf) | pages=413–21 | year=2013}}</ref> in a UK study of 19,729 patients, found that the risk of in-hospital death was significantly higher (OR = 1.12; 95% CI 1.05-1.20) for weekend admission.
===Neurosurgery=== '''''Intracranial haemorrhage''''' Several studies have been published regarding intracranial bleeding: intracerebral, subarachnoid and subdural haemorrhage. In 2009 in the US, Crowley et al.,<ref name="ncbi.nlm.nih.gov">{{cite journal | pmid = 19231928 | doi=10.3171/2008.11.JNS081038 | volume=111 | issue=1 | title=Influence of weekend versus weekday hospital admission on mortality following subarachnoid hemorrhage. Clinical article | author=Crowley RW, Yeoh HK, Stukenborg GJ, Ionescu AA, Kassell NF, Dumont AS | journal=J Neurosurg | pages=60–6 | year=2009}}</ref> in a study of 13,821 US patients with intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH), reported the risk of in-hospital death was 12% higher with weekend admission (OR = 1.12; 95% CI 1.05-1.20). In China, in 2012, Jiang et al.,<ref>{{Cite book | pmid = 21725777 | doi=10.1007/978-3-7091-0693-8_55 | volume=111 | title="Weekend effects" in patients with intracerebral hemorrhage | author=Jiang F, Zhang JH, Qin X | journal=Acta Neurochir Suppl | pages=333–6 | year=2011| series=Acta Neurochirurgica Supplementum | isbn=978-3-7091-0692-1 }}</ref> in a much smaller study (of 313 patients with ICH) found that weekend admission was not a statistically significant predictive factor of in-hospital mortality (p=0.315) or functional outcome (p=0.128). However, in 2016, Patel et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27053981 | doi=10.1177/1941874415601164 | volume=6 | issue=2 | title=A Nationwide Analysis of Outcomes of Weekend Admissions for Intracerebral Hemorrhage Shows Disparities Based on Hospital Teaching Status | pmc=4802773 | author=Patel AA, Mahajan A, Benjo A, Pathak A, Kar J, Jani VB, Annapureddy N, Agarwal SK, Sabharwal MS, Simoes PK, Konstantinidis I, Yacoub R, Javed F, El Hayek G, Menon MC, Nadkarni GN | journal=Neurohospitalist | pages=51–8 | year=2015}}</ref> also in the US, studied 485,329 patients with intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH). Overall, weekend admission was associated with 11% higher odds of in-hospital mortality. When analysed in 3-year groups, excess mortality of weekend admissions showed temporal decline.
Three relatively small studies on SAH have been carried out. Crowley et al.,<ref name="ncbi.nlm.nih.gov"/> in the US in 2009, investigated patients with subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH; 5667 patients). Unlike the group's other study, weekend admission was not a statistically significant independent predictor of death in the study population at 7 days (OR = 1.07, 95% CI 0.91-1.25), 14 days (OR = 1.01, 95% CI 0.87-1.17), or 30 days (OR = 1.03, 95% CI 0.89-1.19). In 2011, in China, Zhang et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 2111694 | volume=35 | issue=2 | title=Effects of zinc oxide-eugenol on leucocyte number and lipoxygenase products in artificially inflamed rat dental pulp | author=Hashimoto S, Maeda M, Yamakita J, Nakamura Y | journal=Arch Oral Biol | pages=87–93 | doi=10.1016/0003-9969(90)90168-a | year=1990}}</ref> in a smaller study, analysed 183 patients with SAH. In logistic regression model, weekend admission was not an independent predictor of higher in-hospital mortality (OR = 1.77, 95% CI 0.83-3.77) after SAH. However a weekend effect was observed by Deshmukh et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26928730 | doi=10.1007/s00701-016-2746-z | volume=158 | issue=5 | title=Effect of weekend admission on in-hospital mortality and functional outcomes for patients with acute subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) | pmc=4826657 | author=Deshmukh H, Hinkley M, Dulhanty L, Patel HC, Galea JP | journal=Acta Neurochir (Wien) | pages=829–35 | year=2016}}</ref> in 2016, when the group studied 385 UK patients with SAH. They found that the patients admitted on a weekend had a significantly higher scan to treatment time (83.1 ± 83.4 h vs 40.4 ± 53.4 h, p<0.0001) and admission to treatment (71.6 ± 79.8 h vs 27.5 ± 44.3 h, p < 0.0001) time. After adjustments for adjusted for relevant covariates, weekend admission was significantly associated with excess in-hospital mortality (OR = 2.1, 95% CI 1.13-4.0; p = 0.01).
In 2013, Busi et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23746103 | doi=10.3171/2013.4.JNS122236 | volume=119 | issue=5 | title=Predictors of mortality in nontraumatic subdural hematoma | author=Busl KM, Prabhakaran S | journal=J Neurosurg | pages=1296–301 | year=2013}}</ref> investigated 14,093 US patients with acute non-traumatic subdural haemorrhage. In multivariate analysis, weekend admission (OR = 1.19; 95% CI 1.02-1.38) was an independent predictor of in-hospital mortality.
Similarly, in 2017, Rumalia et al.,<ref>{{cite journal| pmid=28129634 | doi=10.1016/j.clineuro.2017.01.014 | volume=154 | title=Traumatic subdural hematoma: Is there a weekend effect? | year=2017 | author=Rumalla K, Reddy AY, Mittal MK | journal=Clin Neurol Neurosurg | pages=67–73}}</ref> in an American study of 404,212 patients with traumatic SDH, showed that weekend admission was associated with an increased likelihood of in-hospital complication (OR = 1.06-1.12), prolonged length of stay (OR = 1.08-1.17), and in-hospital mortality (OR: 1.04-1.11).
'''''Other neurosurgical disease''''' In 2012, in the US, Dasenbrook et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21869727 | doi=10.1227/NEU.0b013e318232d1ee | volume=70 | issue=3 | title=The impact of weekend hospital admission on the timing of intervention and outcomes after surgery for spinal metastases | author=Dasenbrock HH, Pradilla G, Witham TF, Gokaslan ZL, Bydon A | journal=Neurosurgery | pages=586–93 | year=2012}}</ref> studied 2714 patients with spinal metastases. Weekend admission was associated with a significantly lower adjusted odds of receiving surgery within 1 day (OR = 0.66; 95% CI 0.54-0.81; p<0.001) and within 2 days (OR = 0.68; 95% CI 0.56-0.83; p<0.001) of admission. But the adjusted odds of in-hospital death was not significantly different for those admitted on the weekend.
In 2012, Schneider et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22795343 | doi=10.1016/j.jss.2012.06.022 | volume=177 | issue=2 | title=Beating the weekend trend: increased mortality in older adult traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients admitted on weekends | author=Schneider EB, Hirani SA, Hambridge HL, Haut ER, Carlini AR, Castillo RC, Efron DT, Haider AH | journal=J Surg Res | pages=295–300 | year=2012}}</ref> also in the US, carried out a study of 38,675 patients with traumatic brain injury. Weekend patients demonstrated 14% increased risk of mortality (OR = 1.14; 95% CI 1.05-1.23). However, Nandyala et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24285275 | doi=10.1097/BRS.0000000000000020 | volume=38 | issue=25 | title=Comparison of perioperative outcomes and cost of spinal fusion for cervical trauma: weekday versus weekend admissions | author=Nandyala SV, Marquez-Lara A, Fineberg SJ, Schmitt DR, Singh K | journal=Spine | pages=2178–83 | year=2013}}</ref> in the following year, in a US study of 34,122 patients who had undergone cervical fusion for cervical spine trauma, found the mortality rate was not significantly different among the weekend patients.
Desai et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26406160 | doi=10.3171/2015.6.PEDS15184 | volume=16 | issue=6 | title=The effect of weekend and after-hours surgery on morbidity and mortality rates in pediatric neurosurgery patients | author=Desai V, Gonda D, Ryan SL, Briceño V, Lam SK, Luerssen TG, Syed SH, Jea A | journal=J Neurosurg Pediatr | pages=726–31 | year=2015}}</ref> in the US, in 2015, investigated 580 children undergoing emergency neurosurgical procedures. After multivariate analysis, children undergoing procedures during a weekday after hours or weekends were more likely to experience complications (p=0.0227), and had an increased mortality.
In 2016, Tanenbaum et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26792199 | pmc=5506776 | doi=10.1016/j.spinee.2015.12.090 | volume=16 | issue=5 | title=Predictors of outcomes and hospital charges following atlantoaxial fusion | author=Tanenbaum JE, Lubelski D, Rosenbaum BP, Thompson NR, Benzel EC, Mroz TE | journal=Spine J | pages=608–18 | year=2016}}</ref> in the US, studied 8,189 patients who had had atlantoaxial fusion. Significant predictors of in-hospital mortality included increased age, emergent or urgent admission, weekend admission, congestive heart failure, coagulopathy, depression, electrolyte disorder, metastatic cancer, neurologic disorder, paralysis, and non-bleeding peptic ulcer.
Atenello et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26544080 | doi=10.3171/2015.6.PEDS15109 | title=Reevaluating the weekend effect on patients with hydrocephalus undergoing operative shunt intervention | author=Attenello FJ, Christian E, Wen T, Cen S, Zada G, Kiehna EN, Krieger MD, McComb JG, Mack WJ | journal=J Neurosurg Pediatr | pages=1–7 | volume=17 | issue=2 | year=2015}}</ref> in 2016, studied 99,472 US paediatric patients with shunted hydrocephalus, 16% of whom were admitted on a weekend. After adjustment for disease severity, time to procedure, and admission acuity, weekend admission was not associated with an increase in the inpatient mortality rate (p=0.46) or a change in the percentage of routine discharges (p=0.98) after ventricular shunt procedures. In addition, associations were unchanged after an evaluation of patients who underwent shunt revision surgery. High-volume centres were incidentally noted in multivariate analysis to have increased rates of routine discharge (OR = 1.04; 95% CI 1.01-1.07; p=0.02).
Also in 2016, Linzey et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27399384 | doi=10.1227/01.neu.0000489675.22357.39 | volume=63 Suppl 1 | title=104 The Effect of Surgical Start Time and Day of the Week on Morbidity and Mortality for Neurological Surgeries | author=Linzey JR, Sabbagh MA, Pandey AS | journal=Neurosurgery | pages=144 | year=2016}}</ref> in the US, studied 15, 865 patients. This were all patients undergoing neurosurgery in a single centre (Michigan). Surgical morbidity was more common during weekend cases vs weekday cases (6.60% vs 4.65%, p=0.03). Surgical mortality during weekend cases was 0.87% compared to only 0.20% during weekdays (p<0.001).
In summary, in neuroscience, the evidence is less clear. In stroke, the weekend effect probably exists. Except for two studies (by Kazley et al.,<ref name=Kazley /> and Hoh et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 207247 | volume=23 | issue=2 | title=A magnetic resonance spin label study of human dental enamel | author=Ferguson S, Chesnut DB | journal=Arch Oral Biol | pages=85–90 | doi=10.1016/0003-9969(78)90144-9 | year=1978}}</ref> both in 2010), all the studies over 20,000 patients show the effect. In neurological/surgical conditions that may require surgery, there is variable evidence of a weekend effect.
==Published research: Disease-specific (selected) patients: Paediatrics and obstetrics== '''''Neonatal mortality''''' Several paediatric and obstetric studies have been performed. In fact, the first studies on the weekend effect were in this area in the late 1970s.
Possibly the first study<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 59692 | volume=13 | issue=4 | title=The specificity and polyvalency of binding of a monoclonal rheumatoid factor | author=Eisenberg R | journal=Immunochemistry | pages=355–9 | doi=10.1016/0019-2791(76)90347-5 | year=1976}}{{cite journal|title=Newcastle survey of deaths in early childhood 1974/76, with special reference to sudden unexpected deaths. Working party for early childhood deaths in Newcastle|journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood|date=November 1977|volume=52|issue=11|pages=828–835|doi=10.1136/adc.52.11.828}}]</ref> of the weekend effect was a UK prospective study of 297,000 children, published in 1977, when childhood deaths were assessed. The paper stated "16 of the 29 sudden unexpected deaths occurred at a weekend or bank holiday".
In 1981, Hendry<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 7306474 | volume=88 | issue=12 | title=The weekend--a dangerous time to be born? | author=Hendry RA | journal=Br J Obstet Gynaecol | pages=1200–3 | year=1981}}</ref> in the UK, stated that "babies born on Sundays were more at risk of dying during or after birth." Also in 1981, in the US, Mangold<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 7235098 | volume=71 | issue=6 | title=Neonatal mortality by the day of the week in the 1974-75 Arkansas live birth cohort | pmc=1619835 | author=Mangold WD | journal=Am J Public Health | pages=601–5 | doi=10.2105/ajph.71.6.601 | year=1981}}<nowiki>]</nowiki>]</ref> studied 66,049 live births. Neonatal mortality was found to be higher among weekend deliveries with a Sunday rate that was 27 per cent above the weekly average. Two years later, in Australia, Mathers<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 6683744 | volume=37 | issue=1 | title=Births and perinatal deaths in Australia: variations by day of week | pmc=1052257 | author=Mathers CD | journal=J Epidemiol Community Health | pages=57–62 | doi=10.1136/jech.37.1.57 | year=1983}}</ref> concluded that "stillbirth and neonatal death rates were 17% and 29% higher respectively among babies born at weekends than among those born on weekdays".
In 2003, Hamilton et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 14649592 | volume=32 | issue=6 | title=Weekend birth and higher neonatal mortality: a problem of patient acuity or quality of care? | author=Hamilton P, Restrepo E | journal=J Obstet Gynecol Neonatal Nurs | pages=724–33 | doi=10.1177/0884217503258306 | year=2003}}</ref> in an American study of 111,749 births, found that neonatal mortality was higher among the births on weekends than those during the week. However, in the same year, Gould et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12799403 | doi=10.1001/jama.289.22.2958 | volume=289 | issue=22 | title=Neonatal mortality in weekend vs weekday births | author=Gould JB, Qin C, Marks AR, Chavez G | journal=JAMA | pages=2958–62 | year=2003}}</ref> also in the US, studied 1,615,041 live births. Observed neonatal mortality increased was 2.80/1000 for weekday births and 3.12/1000 for weekend births (OR = 1.12; 95% CI 1.05-1.19; p=0.001). But after adjusting for birth weight, the increased odds of death for infants born on the weekend were no longer significant.
In 2004, Luo et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 14757669 | volume=170 | issue=3 | title=Risks of stillbirth and early neonatal death by day of week | pmc=331383 | author=Luo ZC, Liu S, Wilkins R, Kramer MS | journal=CMAJ | pages=337–41 | year=2004}}</ref> studied 3,239,972 births recorded in Canada. The proportion of births on weekend days was 24% lower than the proportion on weekdays. Infants born on weekend days had slightly but significantly elevated risks of stillbirth (OR = 1.06, 95% CI 1.02-1.09) and early neonatal death (OR = 1.11, 95% CI 1.07-1.16). However, the higher risks disappeared after adjustment for gestational age.
Salihu et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22487462 | doi=10.1111/j.1447-0756.2011.01818.x | volume=38 | issue=7 | title=Risk of infant mortality with weekend versus weekday births: a population-based study | author=Salihu HM, Ibrahimou B, August EM, Dagne G | journal=J Obstet Gynaecol Res | pages=973–9 | year=2012}}</ref> in another American study, in 2012, found that the neonatal mortality rate was higher on weekends (3.25/1000) compared to weekdays (2.87/1000)(p=0.042). In the same year, Ibrahimou et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22797696 | doi=10.1007/s00404-012-2463-7 | volume=286 | issue=6 | title=Twins born over weekends: are they at risk for elevated infant mortality? | author=Ibrahimou B, Salihu HM, English G, Anozie C, Lartey G, Dagne G | journal=Arch Gynecol Obstet | pages=1349–55 | year=2012}}</ref> in a US study of twin births, found post-neonatal mortality risk was higher on weekends as compared to weekdays (OR = 1.19; 95% CI 1.04-1.36). Also twins born on weekends to teenage mothers (age<18) had a 35% greater risk for neonatal death (OR = 1.35; 95% CI 1.06-1.71.
In 2015, Palmer et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26602245 | volume=351 | title=Association between day of delivery and obstetric outcomes: observational study | pmc=4658392 | author=Palmer WL, Bottle A, Aylin P | journal=BMJ | pages=h5774|doi=10.1136/bmj.h5774 | year=2015}}</ref> in the UK carried out an observational study on outcomes from maternal and neonatal records; on 1,332,835 deliveries and 1,349,599 births. They found that performance across four of seven measures was significantly worse for women admitted, and babies born, at weekends. In particular, the perinatal mortality rate was 7.3 per 1000 babies delivered at weekends; 0.9 per 1000 higher than for weekdays (OR = 1.07; 95% CI 1.02-1.13). No consistent association between outcomes and staffing was identified, although trusts that complied with recommended levels of consultant presence had a perineal tear rate of 3.0% compared with 3.3% for non-compliant services (OR = 1.21; 95% CI 1.00-1.45.
The authors went on to make a prediction regarding the possible benefits of removing the ‘weekend effect’: "The results would suggest approximately 770 perinatal deaths and 470 maternal infections per year above what might be expected if performance was consistent across women admitted, and babies born, on different days of the week."
'''''Other paediatric disease''''' Mitchell et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 3250410 | volume=18 | issue=7 | title=Deaths from sudden infant death syndrome on public holidays and weekends | author=Mitchell EA, Stewart AW | journal=Aust N Z J Med | pages=861–3 | doi=10.1111/j.1445-5994.1988.tb01646.x | year=1988}}</ref> in New Zealand in 1988, carried out a small study of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). Examination of deaths by day of the week, and showed the weekend had more deaths than the weekdays (p=0.0002).
Goldstein et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24952794 | doi=10.1016/j.jpedsurg.2014.01.001 | volume=49 | issue=7 | title=The "weekend effect" in pediatric surgery - increased mortality for children undergoing urgent surgery during the weekend | author=Goldstein SD, Papandria DJ, Aboagye J, Salazar JH, Van Arendonk K, Al-Omar K, Ortega G, Sacco Casamassima MG, Abdullah F | journal=J Pediatr Surg | pages=1087–91 | year=2014}}</ref> in 2014, studied 439,457 US paediatric patients who underwent a range of surgical procedures. After multivariate adjustment and regression, patients undergoing a weekend procedure were more likely to die (OR = 1.63; 95% CI 1.21-2.20).
Burstein et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27084114 | doi=10.1016/j.injury.2016.02.021 | volume=47 | issue=6 | title=Increased morbidity associated with weekend paediatric road traffic injuries: 10-year analysis of trauma registry data | author=Burstein B, Fauteux-Lamarre E, As AB | journal=Injury | pages=1236–41 | year=2016}}</ref> in a study of 71,180 South African paediatric trauma patients found that 8,815 (12.4%) resulted from Road Traffic Accidents. RTAs were more common on weekends than weekdays (2.98 vs 2.19 patients/day; p<0.001), representing a greater proportion of daily all-cause trauma (15.5% vs 11.2%; p<0.001). Moreover, weekend RTA patients sustained more severe injuries than on weekdays, and compared to weekend all-cause trauma patients (injury score 1.66 vs. 1.46 and 1.43; both p<0.001).
In obstetric and paediatrics, most studies did show a weekend effect. This is a concern as both specialties, traditionally, have similar work patterns throughout the week.
==Published research: Disease-specific (selected) patients: Specialist surgery==
===General surgery=== The weekend effect have been assessed in a wide range of specific surgical conditions. Four studies were published in 2012. Worni et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22411091 | doi=10.1007/s00268-012-1550-z | volume=36 | issue=7 | title=Laparoscopic appendectomy outcomes on the weekend and during the week are no different: a national study of 151,774 patients | author=Worni M, Østbye T, Gandhi M, Rajgor D, Shah J, Shah A, Pietrobon R, Jacobs DO, Guller U | journal=World J Surg | pages=1527–33 | year=2012}}</ref> in the US, studied 151,774 patients who had had a laparoscopic appendectomy. Overall mortality (OR = 1.37; p=0.075) was not statistically different between weekday and weekend groups. Whereas the same group, found a weekend effect in a study of 31,832 patients who underwent urgent surgery for left-sided diverticulitis (Worni et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22802061 | doi=10.1001/archsurg.2012.825 | volume=147 | issue=7 | title=Worse outcomes in patients undergoing urgent surgery for left-sided diverticulitis admitted on weekends vs weekdays: a population-based study of 31 832 patients | author=Worni M, Schudel IM, Østbye T, Shah A, Khare A, Pietrobon R, Thacker JK, Guller U | journal=Arch Surg | pages=649–55 | year=2012}}</ref> 2012). In a risk-adjusted analysis, patients admitted on weekends had a significantly higher risk for any postoperative complication (OR = 1.10; p=0.005). A mortality analysis was not presented.
In the same year, in a small study of 404 US patients with small bowel obstruction, McVay et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25008263 | doi=10.1093/gastro/gou043 | volume=2 | issue=3 | title=The weekend effect: does time of admission impact management and outcomes of small bowel obstruction? | pmc=4124276 | author=McVay DP, Walker AS, Nelson DW, Porta CR, Causey MW, Brown TA | journal=Gastroenterol Rep (Oxf) | pages=221–5 | year=2014}}</ref> found that mortality was low at 1.7%, with no difference noted between the groups (p=0.35). This is not surprising with a small study of a lowish risk procedure. In the US, Orman et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22271668 | doi=10.1002/lt.23395 | volume=18 | issue=5 | title=Impact of nighttime and weekend liver transplants on graft and patient outcomes | pmc=3334405 | author=Orman ES, Hayashi PH, Dellon ES, Gerber DA, Barritt AS 4th | journal=Liver Transpl | pages=558–65 | year=2012}}</ref> studied 94,768 liver transplant patients. Unadjusted Cox proportional hazards modelling showed that in comparison with weekday liver transplant patients, weekend liver transplant patients had an OR of 0.99 (95% CI 0.93-1.07) for mortality at 30 days (i.e. no weekend effect).
In 2017, Hoehn et al.,<ref>Hoehn RS, Hanseman DJ, Chang AL, Daly MC, Ertel AE, Abbott DE, Shah SA, Paquette IM. Surgeon Characteristics Supersede Hospital Characteristics in Mortality After Urgent Colectomy. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27586190 J Gastrointest Surg. 2017 Jan; 21(1): 23-32]</ref> in the USA, studied 50,707 patients who had undergone urgent colectomy. They found, on multivariate analysis, mortality was associated with patient age (10 years: OR = 1.31, p < 0.01), severity of illness (extreme: OR = 34.68, p < 0.01), insurance status (Medicaid: OR = 1.24, p < 0.01; uninsured: OR = 1.40, p < 0.01), and weekend admission (OR = 1.09, p = 0.04).
===Trauma and orthopaedics=== In 2011, Carr et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21422328 | doi=10.1001/archsurg.2011.60 | volume=146 | issue=7 | title=Weekend and night outcomes in a statewide trauma system | author=Carr BG, Reilly PM, Schwab CW, Branas CC, Geiger J, Wiebe DJ | journal=Arch Surg | pages=810–7 | year=2011}}</ref> carried out a study of 90,461 US patients with trauma. The authors found that patients presenting on weekends were less likely to die than patients presenting on weekdays (OR = 0.89; 95% CI 0.81-0.97). This is one of only two studies that have shown weekend mortality is less at the weekend.
There have been four studies looking at fracture of the neck of femur. In 2012, Daugaard et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23140106 | doi=10.3109/17453674.2012.747926 | volume=83 | issue=6 | title=Is mortality after hip fracture associated with surgical delay or admission during weekends and public holidays? A retrospective study of 38,020 patients | pmc=3555458 | author=Daugaard CL, Jørgensen HL, Riis T, Lauritzen JB, Duus BR, van der Mark S | journal=Acta Orthop | pages=609–13 | year=2012}}</ref> carried out a study on 38,020 Danish patients with a fractured neck of femur. The mortality rate for patients admitted during weekends or public holidays, or at night, was similar to that found for those admitted during working days. Whereas, two years later, Thomas et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24589794 | doi=10.1302/0301-620X.96B3.33118 | volume=96-B | issue=3 | title=The weekend effect: short-term mortality following admission with a hip fracture | author=Thomas CJ, Smith RP, Uzoigwe CE, Braybrooke JR | journal=Bone Joint J | pages=373–8 | year=2014}}</ref> in a much smaller UK of 2989 consecutive patients, found that (whether managed surgically or conservatively), patients were more likely to die as an inpatient when admitted at the weekend (OR = 1.4, 95% CI 1.02-1.80; p=0.032).
However, in a US study of 344,989 patients with fractured neck of femur, in 2015, the opposite effect was found (Boylan et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26447407 | volume=44 | issue=10 | title=Hip Fracture and the Weekend Effect: Does Weekend Admission Affect Patient Outcomes? | author=Boylan MR, Rosenbaum J, Adler A, Naziri Q, Paulino CB | journal=Am J Orthop (Belle Mead NJ) | pages=458–64 | year=2015}}</ref>). Compared with patients admitted on weekdays, patients admitted on weekends had lower mortality (OR = 0.94; 95% CI 0.89-0.99) and shorter mean hospital stay (estimate, 3.74%; 95% CI 3.40-4.08); but did not differ in risk of perioperative complications (OR = 1.00; 95% CI 0.98-1.02). The authors concluded: "our study data do not support a weekend effect among hip fracture admissions in the United States". This is second study where a ‘weekday effect’ has been found.
In 2016, in Denmark, Kristiansen et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27097886 | doi=10.1093/intqhc/mzw037 | volume=28 | issue=3 | title=Off-hours admission and quality of hip fracture care: a nationwide cohort study of performance measures and 30-day mortality | author=Kristiansen NS, Kristensen PK, Nørgård BM, Mainz J, Johnsen SP | journal=Int J Qual Health Care | pages=324–31 | year=2016}}</ref> investigated 25,305 patients undergoing hip fracture surgery. When comparing admission during weekends with admission during weekdays, off-hours admission was associated with a higher risk of surgical delay (OR = 1.19; 95% CI 1.05-1.37) and a higher 30-day mortality risk (OR = 1.13; 95% CI 1.04-1.23). They felt that "The risk of surgical delay appeared not to explain the excess 30-day mortality".
Three studies on major or polytrauma were carried out in 2016. Dei Giudici et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26312113 | doi=10.2174/1874325001509010296 | volume=9 | title=Orthopaedic Timing in Polytrauma in a Second Level Emergency Hospital. An Overrated Problem? | pmc=4541330 | author=Dei Giudici L, Giampaolini N, Panfighi A, Marinelli M, Procaccini R, Gigante A | journal=Open Orthop J | pages=296–302 | year=2015}}</ref> carried out a small study (of 208 Italian polytrauma patients). No correlation between mortality and orthopaedic surgical timing was found.
Also in 2016, in the UK, Giannoudis et al.<ref>Giannoudis V, Panteli M, Giannoudis PV. Management of polytrauma patients in the UK: Is there a 'weekend effect'? [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27809989 Injury. 2016 Nov; 47(11): 2385-2390]</ref> studied 1735 patients, and found mortality was lower in the weekend group: 39/360 pts (10.8%) compared to the weekday group: 100/670 pts (14.9%) but this did not reach statistical significance p=0.07). The relative risk (RR) of weekend mortality was 0.726 (95% CI: 0.513-1.027).
In another study on major trauma in 2016, in all 22 UK major trauma centres (MTC), Metcalfe et al.,<ref>Metcalfe D, Perry DC, Bouamra O, Salim A, Lecky FE, Woodford M, Edwards A, Costa ML. Is there a 'weekend effect' in major trauma? [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27789565 Emerg Med J. 2016 Dec; 33(12): 836-842]</ref> investigated 49,070 patients. Using multivariable logistic regression models, odds of secondary transfer into an MTC were higher at night (OR = 2.05, 95% CI 1.93-2.19) but not during the day at weekends (OR = 1.09; CI 0.99-1.19). Neither admission at night nor at the weekend was associated with increased length of stay, or higher odds of in-hospital death.
===Vascular surgery=== Two studies of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) have been carried out. Both demonstrated the weekend effect. In 2012, Gellerani et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22542339 | doi=10.1016/j.jvs.2011.11.133 | volume=55 | issue=5 | title=Higher mortality in patients hospitalized for acute aortic rupture or dissection during weekends | author=Gallerani M, Imberti D, Bossone E, Eagle KA, Manfredini R | journal=J Vasc Surg | pages=1247–54 | year=2012}}</ref> in Italy, investigated 4461 patients. Weekend admissions were associated with significantly higher in-hospital mortality (43.4%) than weekday admissions (36.9%; p<0.001). Multivariate regression analysis showed that weekend admission was an independent risk factor for increased in-hospital mortality (OR = 1.32; 95% CI 1.14-1.52; p<0.001). Two years later, in the US, in a study of 5832 patients, Groves et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24709439 | doi=10.1016/j.jvs.2014.02.052 | volume=60 | issue=2 | title=Effects of weekend admission on the outcomes and management of ruptured aortic aneurysms | pmc=4121436 | author=Groves EM, Khoshchehreh M, Le C, Malik S | journal=J Vasc Surg | pages=318–24 | year=2014}}</ref> found that patients admitted on the weekend had a statistically significant increase in mortality compared with those admitted on the weekdays (OR = 1.32; 95% CI 1.13-1.55; p=0.0004).
There are also two studies on lower limb ischaemia, both performed in the US. In a study of 63,768 patients with an ischaemic lower limb in 2014, Orandi et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25441678 | doi=10.1016/j.jvs.2014.08.091 | volume=60 | issue=6 | title=Outcomes of nonelective weekend admissions for lower extremity ischemia | author=Orandi BJ, Selvarajah S, Orion KC, Lum YW, Perler BA, Abularrage CJ | journal=J Vasc Surg | pages=1572–9.e1 | year=2014}}</ref> found no statistically significant association between weekend admission and in-hospital mortality (OR = 1.15; 95% CI 1.06-1.25; p=0.10). Whereas, Arora et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26100585 | doi=10.1016/j.amjcard.2015.05.050 | volume=116 | issue=5 | title=Impact of Hospital Volume on Outcomes of Lower Extremity Endovascular Interventions (Insights from the Nationwide Inpatient Sample [2006 to 2011]) | author=Arora S, Panaich SS, Patel N, Patel N, Lahewala S, Solanki S, Patel P, Patel A, Manvar S, Savani C, Tripathi B, Thakkar B, Jhamnani S, Singh V, Patel S, Patel J, Bhimani R, Mohamad T, Remetz MS, Curtis JP, Attaran RR, Grines C, Mena CI, Cleman M, Forrest J, Badheka AO | journal=Am J Cardiol | pages=791–800 | year=2015}}<nowiki>]</nowiki>). Am J Cardiol. 2015 Sep 1; 116(5): 791–800]</ref> a year later, in a similar study, did show a weekend effect. They found through multivariate analysis, that weekend admission (OR = 1.53; 95% CI 1.26-1.86; p<0.001) was a significant predictor of inhospital mortality.
In 2015, Tadisina et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26019238 | doi=10.1093/asj/sjv088 | volume=35 | issue=8 | title=The "weekend effect" in plastic surgery: analyzing weekday versus weekend admissions in body contouring procedures from 2000 to 2010 | author=Tadisina KK, Chopra K, Singh DP | journal=Aesthet Surg J | pages=995–8 | year=2015}}</ref> carried out the only study so far published on plastic surgery, investigating 50,346 US patients who had body contouring procedures. The authors found mortality rates to be higher on weekend admissions (3.7%) vs weekdays (0.5%). This is very surprising as presumably these are low risk operations.
===Other specialist surgery=== The first ENT study was carried out in the UK in 2016 by Patel et al.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 27292442 | doi=10.1017/S0022215116008161 | volume=130 | issue=8 | title=Is weekend surgery a risk factor for post-tonsillectomy haemorrhage? | author=Patel A, Foden N, Rachmanidou A | journal=J Laryngol Otol | pages=763–7 | year=2016}}</ref> The authors found that 2208 elective tonsillectomies were performed on a weekday and 141 on the weekend. Post-tonsillectomy haemorrhages occurred in 104 patients (4.7%) who underwent the procedure on a weekday and in 10 patients (7.1%) who had surgery at the weekend (p = 0.20), i.e. not significantly different.
Also in 2016, Sayari et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26932247 | doi=10.1016/j.jpedsurg.2016.02.014 | volume=51 | issue=5 | title=Weekday vs. weekend repair of esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula | author=Sayari AJ, Tashiro J, Wang B, Perez EA, Lasko DS, Sola JE | journal=J Pediatr Surg | pages=739–42 | year=2016}}</ref> in the US, carried out a small study of (861) patients with esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula (EA/TEF). The cohort survival was 96%. Complication rates were higher with EA/TEF repair on a weekend (OR: 2.2) compared to a weekday. However weekend vs weekday procedure had no significant effect on mortality.
Blackwell et al.,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 26804754 | pmc=5207476 | doi=10.1016/j.juro.2016.01.056 | volume=196 | issue=1 | title=Early Intervention during Acute Stone Admissions: Revealing "The Weekend Effect" in Urological Practice | author=Blackwell RH, Barton GJ, Kothari AN, Zapf MA, Flanigan RC, Kuo PC, Gupta GN | journal=J Urol | pages=124–30 | year=2016}}</ref> in the US, also in 2016, studied 10,301 patients who were admitted urgently for nephrolithiasis with obstruction to the renal tract. Weekend day admission significantly influenced time to intervention, and decreased the likelihood of intervention by 26% (p<0.001).
In summary, across a range of surgical conditions, little pattern was obvious with some conditions showing a weekend effect (e.g. small bowel obstruction and AAA) but others not (appendicitis and diverticulitis). In fractured neck of femur, two studies showed a weekend effect, two did not.
==Published research: Summary== In summary, in a majority (over 60%) of the over 190 studies described above, mortality is increased if the patient is admitted at the weekend. Of these, there are 56 very large studies (of over 100,000 patients). These have included 27.5 million (27514157) patients. Of these 56 studies, 29 concern patients in the USA, and 11 in the UK or England. 25 are non-disease specific, 31 disease specific. 49/56 (88%) show the weekend effect, 6 no effect, one ([https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26447407 Boylan et al], on fracture neck of femur) shows a weekday effect. All of the UK-based >100,000 patient studies show the weekend effect.
22/56 of these >100,000 patient studies, were carried out on over 1 million patients. Of these, 20/22 (91%) show the weekend effect, and 2 no effect (both neonatal mortality). The median relative risk (RR) of these papers is 1.11 (range 0.94-3.18), i.e. patients admitted at weekends are, on average, 11% more likely to die than those admitted in the week. This data takes into account confounding variables, as all these papers use regression analysis.
